review:
Why I hate and don't recommend the game:
1) The 58 Japanese lessons you read like a lazy game tutorial 
2) The tests are at the end of every week, they get harder, later weeks you take 2 to 3 tests in one sitting, you only have 60 seconds to finish a test or it's an automatic game over. 
3) There are typos and grammar errors in the lessons or tests.
4) The story is about an American teen boy who dreamed about going to Japan and attend his dream school. But the problem is he's flat broke after getting into Japan so he lives in a girl's only boarding house with his female classmates. Also stupid American MC lies on his resume to the principal and he can't speak Japanese. So instead of rejecting him, the principal decides to bombard the MC (and us) with lessons and tests to prove he's qualified to be at the school.
5) When the game allows you to breathe and have a social life you can interact with one girl per day. If you stick with one girl, she'll be your girlfriend at the end of the playthrough. Problem is said girl will not always be available everyday, choose the right dialogue boxes for extra love points and have 5 dates with her (hanging out doesn't count). If you did everything accurately she's your gf at the end of your run if not your single and  have to try again from the beginning.
6) The characters at best are just generic  visual novel characters. They get boring fast and you (the player) would be more worried about studying.
7) Text skip speed is the slowest I've ever experienced in a visual novel even on the "fastest" setting. 
8) If you're a completionist, DON'T GET THIS GAME. While the achievements are not objectively hard to get you need to play the game 5 times minimum to get everything. Everything I complained about above you deal with them 5 times or more if you messed up. I heavily recommend cheat engine.

If you're genuinely interested in learning Japanese don't buy this game. First of all for a game or even a VN it's boring. There's no creative fun gameplay to have what you learn stick so the lessons are equivalent to studying with PowerPoint slides. The game is like school where it just reads the lessons, demands you to study when you have free time and demands you to pass every single otherwise it boots you out for being lazy and stupid so there's no flexibility to learn or take the tests at your pace. Also just like school the tests throw harder questions that weren't covered in the lessons. The further I played the game, I forget what I learnt, no longer cared about learning anything and I resorted to cheating on the tests using Cheat Engine to pause the time and use the game's slides or Google Image translation. I feel like if a school made a visual novel it would be Love Language Japanese, Heck there's a part in the story where you go to the beach and you're forced to endure lessons.

You can only either beat this game if you're already familiar with Japanese or like me use Cheat Engine

review: After a long break from studying Japanese I picked this game up as a fun way to review what I already knew. I think it works really well as a fun revision tool for very basic Japanese ~ but I would only recommend it you've been through a beginner textbook and started learning hiragana and katakana. The lessons are brief and basic and do not contain sufficient explanations to be able to pass the tests without a lot of trial and error, unless you do have some prior knowledge. On the story side of things, the plot was amusing enough to keep me playing regularly, but I probably wouldn't have finished the game if I wasn't playing it for the Japanese practice. The game itself is a great idea but I think it would really benefit from a few additions, such as an option to turn off romaji in the lessons, some actual in-game Japanese conversation practice with the girls (all conversations are in English), and a good proof-read to get rid of the English (and occasionally Japanese) typos.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987527539', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 1567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1567, 'last_played': 1640535989}
review:
I'd give it a thumbs sideways, but I can't.

First and foremost - the game's been abandoned for almost three years now. All the bugs, typos and generic missing content will not be fixed, ever.

It's merely decent for learning some very basic language - it will teach you some very basic things (and even has explanations), but the learning content is pretty much confined to the lessons themselves, there's no immersion in the VN or any minigames (those were promised before the developer dissolved). The japanese course has plenty of errors, typos and inconsistencies (like tests having words you were never taught). Besides that, tests themselves are time trials and nothing more. And it does not teach you kanji, even for words it already teaches.

It's pretty meh as a VN - there is one straight line and the only events you can get are dates (which do not change the plot at all). Besides that, if you intend to replay, the skip is quite slow and the lessons/tests are an obligatory part of the game, so replaying takes quite some time. In terms of variety and building score - even with vigorous save scumming you might very well miss the final date merely because you gave a suboptimal answer in one of the early dialogues.

Overall I can't recommend this game too much except in case you quite like the visuals, desperately want some basic japanese with your VN and do not mind missing out on the final date (which is a big goal, presumably).

author: {'steamid': '76561198026507521', 'num_games_owned': 30, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1630818079}
review:
So i've been playing this game for about 2 hours so far. I don't know if I'll ever bother finishing it, so here's a review.

Score for learning Japanese
2/5

I have self-studied japanese on and off for a number of years. My understanding is rudimentary, mainly because I keep forgetting everything I know. I'm able to follow the lessons and benefit somewhat from the new vocab, but that's about it. The game is basically here's a bunch of stuff to memorize. Now we're going to ask you yes or no questions about some of it - including stuff that you weren't even taught.

Score for dating game:
2/5 
I haven't played many dating games, but this one isn't very fun to play. You are constantly having to do the lessos, it's non optional, and each day, you get 1 choice, maybe 2 towards the characters. Everything else is auto. it would have been very easy to actually give you more choices within the structure of the game, but instead it just feels like a pointless grind.

Score for art
4/5
For what it is, it's perfectly fine. The art looks good, the characters are interesting enough, if stereotypical. 

Score for characters
Max is easily the worst part of the game. One of the characters is your standard hates boys. The way the teacher is so up in your grill without any choice over the matter is kinda weird. Really it feels like you have one real romantic prospect and the others are there to give the pretense of having a selection. 

I bought this game because I had already read reviews about the ability to learn Japanese from it being average at best, but I was looking for something to motivate me to pick up my Japanese habit again. Unfortunately, this is an extremely average language learning game and a fairly annoying dating game. I'm convinced that all of the concepts are here to make this into a decent game, but from what I've seen so far, they haven't put in the time and care to execute that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158945336', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1239, 'last_played': 1628705601}
review:
Après avoir fini le jeu en une vingtaine d'heures (en prenant des notes), je vous recommande ce jeu car il vous permettra d'apprendre les caractères hiragana et katakana ainsi que du vocabulaire, grammaire et conjugaison. De plus, ce jeu est un visual novel mais avec quelques phases de gameplay pour répondre à des questions.

De mon point de vue, le jeu est une bonne façon d'apprendre mais il faut bosser sur le côté car chaque jour dans le jeu représente une apprentissage et c'est assez difficile au début de tout retenir, donc il faut être motivé à prendre des notes ou déjà avoir quelques bases.
Personnellement, je recommande l'utilisation des jeux de la saga "Learn Japanese" pour vous familiariser avec les caractères japonais avant de jouer à ce jeu.

L'histoire est assez basique mais donne un peu de peps au jeu en sortant de certaines phase de routine.

En dehors de ça, le jeu possède parfois quelques erreurs et bugs, j'ai déjà eu un softlock et des dialogues qui ne s'effaçais pas.

Pour finir, malgré les quelques défauts présent je recommande ce jeu si vous souhaitez apprendre les bases de la grammaire et du vocabulaire japonais.

Pour information, une bonne maîtrise de l'anglais est quand même nécessaire pour permettre de traduire correctement les traductions japonais - anglais mais également avoir assez de temps lors des exercices.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992098475', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3571, 'last_played': 1703779384}
review:
I thoroughly enjoyed this game and it led me to invest further in learning Japanese. 

It teaches Japanese basics: hiragana, katakana and basic topics such as counting and telling time. It does not go into kanji (except the very last lesson introduces the kanji for the four directions north, east, west and south). You will need to take notes and create your own flash cards as it does not provide good vocabulary drills. As with learning any language, you get out of it what you put in, so will do some learning outside of the game.

You are a guy who has cheated on the entrance exam to a prestigious school teaching Japanese. As a punishment you are sent to the absolute beginners class and have to pass a test every Saturday or you will be expelled. As there are not enough dorm rooms available you get to room in an otherwise all-girls dorm. You can pursue various romantic interests, eventually leading to dates but don't expect anything spicy here. There may be some suggestive content but in general it's probably even safe for children. What you see in the Steam store page is about as hot as it gets.

The learning Japanese part is quite divorced from the dating sim part. Apart from doing your homework in your bedroom in the evening, you don't use Japanese outside of the school. We get introduced to the use of tadaima (I'm back home) and okaerinasai (welcome back) but then it is not used again. It would have been nice to see some common phrases scattered around your day, perhaps shown in kana.

If you don't know Japanese and are not interested in learning it you will not get much out of it as your progress will be blocked by tests. If you know more than very basic Japanese the dating sim part alone is probably not worth buying at full price. However, if you are an absolute beginner with an interest in Japanese this game is what you have been looking for to get you motivated to finally start learning.

There is quite a few things that could be done better but I am happy with the game. With such a narrow target audience one can't really expect a ton of money being put in its production.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083974456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 3791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1088, 'last_played': 1631111248}
review:
Специализируюсь на образовательных играх (1й в Мире канал по этой тематике), прошел с 5к и знаю с 10к игр по обучению Японскому. Эту игру прохожу у себя на канале: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l1L8VvmFvRI&list=PLkGyZcxsQFo1eUE7sWIRNUM6TMTBt3zXr

Минусы:
1) ООООООООООЧЕНЬ затянутое начало! 2 часа диалогов до 1го урока! Это самая затянутая обучающая игра, из всех, что знаю.
2) Отсутствует достаточное число повторений материала, чтобы его запомнить - игра подходит для повторения, когда Вы уже учили Хирагану и Катакану, и Канзи.
3) Отсутствие системности в преподавании уроков 
3.1- в уроках ничего не говорят про дайкутены и не показывают вместе каны с и без дайкутенов, что ЗНАЧИТЕЛЬНО замедляет запоимнание.
3.2- не показывают одинаковые каны в двух азбуках Хараганы и Катаканы
3.3- нет уроков для распознавания очень похожих символов, чтобы перестать в них путаться. 
3.4 Хотелось бы выбирать правильные распространенные фразы и слова во время общения - правильно здороваться, прощаться, обращаться к людям...
4. Игра строго на английском языке, но в своих видео - Я все переводил.

Плюсы:
1) Весело - атмосфера позитивненького анимэ про школу и гарем девиц.
2) Эротично - Вас все хотят и постоянно на это намекают. Это приятно.
3) Хентай - большинство персонажей взято из хентай игр, так что можно найти их обнаженные версии.
4) есть примеры многих слов во время уроков.
Итог: игра хороша только для повторения, а начинать изучение с 0 лучше с серии Learn Japanese To Survive.

Следите за Моим каналом, будет больше игр по изучению Японского и других языков.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025198474', 'num_games_owned': 838, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1613942503}
review:
I am half way through this game at the time of this writing. That is almost six hours, so if you are considering it, expect to take about 12 hours to play through once.
What drew me to getting this was the idea of a visual novel that is designed as both an instructional tool, as well as a dating sim. In many ways it fills both of those slots, but at the same time, it is not without problems.

First of all, the good:
The story is cute, as are the cast of girls you have to chose from. Like most dating sims, it does not tell you how to win the hearts of your chosen girl and you have to stumble around figuring it out. This I think is good as it will mix up future playthroughs, which will only serve to strengthen the lessons.
Your initial lessons are in Hiragana and Katakana, followed by sound combinations. Understanding there, as in being able to sight-read them without effort is essential to developing good skill in Japanese. This is by far the greatest strength in this game. If a player puts in the effort, they can learn one of the most important foundational skills they need for effective learning. However, this focus on these alphabets comes at a price.

The Bad:
Typos? They exist. Every game of this kind has typos. Move on.
This game focuses on Hiragana, Katakana, and sound combinations. While those are good to know, and can help with Kanji learning via Furigana, the simple fact is, you need to know the Kanji for what you are learning. When dealing with Japanese, be it in games, manga, anime, newspapers, or any other media, you will be confronted with Kanji, and knowing how to read it as it is presented will make it much easier to practice, and keep your skills up.
But, I think my main complaint about this game is the total lack of proper explanation of the use of は as a particle. The game consistently refers to the particle は as Ha instead of Wa in all of the Romanji. This will set a beginner in Japanese with a very bad habit that, while forgivable, can be very embarrassing, as well as hard to change later in learning. Bad habits formed in the beginning can be very hard to overcome later in the cycle.

Overall, I feel it is a good game. It has a fun cast, an enjoyable storyline filled with every trope you can imagine, appropriate music, and will help you recognize some basic building blocks of Japanese. Maybe it will even teach you a few words and a little grammar along the way.

review: This game is the hub around which all my other Japanese learning resources revolve.  I have apps, books, websites, but progressing through Love Language Japanese is my main objective. [spoiler]You play the role of a foreign student who lied on his application to get admitted to a prestigious Japanese school.  His lie is found out, but they let him stay on the condition that he passes weekly tests.  If you fail a single test, you are expelled from the school and it's game over.  Helpful hint: save your game right before each test.  That way if you flunk out, you can easily get back to it to retake the test. It's kind of like a harem game because there is only one other male character. The women at the school make the game fun and interesting.  I did fail one test and got expelled. After that I buckled down and studied my other resources, then came back at a save point before the test and passed it.  I'm developing a crush on one of the girls.  She may be waifu material for me.[/spoiler]  The lessons are just right: not too hard and not too easy.  You do have to be serious about learning Japanese to enjoy this game.  I recommend you get supplemental  resources to help you learn your hiragana and katakana. There are two things I don't like: 1) When I go into settings to turn down the background music so I can listen to pronunciation, the change in the setting doesn't stay.  So I have to turn the music down every time I use the program. 2) Everything is timed.  That is understandable for tests, but exercises are also timed.  That is counterproductive because I need time to figure things out sometimes. Those minuses aside, I highly recommend Love Language Japanese for the serious weeb or learner of Japanese. [spoiler]Learning a language requires sustained effort over a long period of time and so your motivation will probably fade. Love Language Japanese keeps you motivated with  the cute girls and the very attractive professor, and the lovely dean of the school. The girls have kept me coming back and I keep learning Japanese.[/spoiler] I can't say enough good things about this game. At $20 it is a bargain. I am so happy to have found it.  Another game I recommend for beginning Japanese is Nihongo School.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036535976', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 680, 'last_played': 1600070079}
review:
Went into this not expecting much, but it's doing a better job at getting Japanese to stick than some textbooks. The basic premise of the game is that you've made up a bs story to get accepted into a selective Japanese language school. As you got caught lying on your application, you are punished by being put back into the beginners class. Fortunately, or unfortunately, for you, there was also a mixup in your living arrangements and so you end up living with a bunch of cute girls in an all girls dorm.

I started this game wanting to learn Japanese, and not so much do the dating parts, but I can't say I wasn't interested in the dating aspect either. So I can forgive the cheesy as heck plot, even if it is cringy at times. I do like that you can date some "older" ladies, though I guess they're younger than I am, but not the mc.

Each day is segmented as a lesson, after lesson activities, some after school activities to raise your love meter with various girls, and then end of day activities (such as revision). At the end of each week, you have to do an exam and pass it, otherwise you get sent back home as per your punishment for lying to get into the school. I like this approach to the design as it follows what is a regular school day, at least from what my ancient memory recalls it being like.

The writing, on the whole, is pretty okay. It's not high literature, it's mostly just ego stroking for the player to reward them for staying in the game. Working towards a goal that is more than just learning the language is more helpful, at least for me. It's kinda like if you go to the gym to train but have no goal for the reason for training, and so you will burn out and quit. But as long as you're working towards a goal, you'll stay in the game.

Lessons in this game start off really basic, like あ = a, for example, but eventually become more and more complicated as you go. I feel like some of these lessons could have been condensed together earlier on, but it works the way it was done. As you progress, the end of week exams become more complicated as well. In the beginning you play match up like A = ? and a bunch of choices appear on the screen to choose from. But eventually you're substituting words or letters in words within a sentence. Each exam also only lasts for a minute and there are 10 questions in each. At the start, it'll seem easy, but if you don't actually learn the material, you'll get stuck later. One of the biggest criticisms of this system is that I think only 50% is a passing mark, which means that you can essentially just guess your way through the game. Have you really learned anything if you only know half the material? A 50% at the start will show the cracks at even 3-4 weeks in the game, where you'll just end up failing. My second criticism here, though it's also a positive, is that the 1minute window is too short, especially if you're reading new words or concepts. Though this does also improve your ability to read quickly, it also allows you to just game the tests if you read only say, the first word of a sentence and the missing letter is there, so you neglect the rest of the sentence which might be a detriment to learning.

I feel like if you fly through the game though, you'll have a hard time with it, and so I've implemented a few rules that I do in each of the in-game days of learning.
1. Do the lesson
2. Take the lesson quiz at the end of the lesson 3 times.
3. If I don't 100% a quiz, I reset my counter and need to 3 more lessons at 100%
4. Do the all lessons study at the end of the day with the same rule as 3.
5. Review lessons if needed
6. Do one week of this per real world day to prevent burnout or mental strain. So that's 5 days lessons, 1 day exam.
You could probably also hand write your lessons too so you get used to writing in Japanese if you wanted to. Much like any learning material, you only get as much out of it as you put into it!

There are, however, a few bugs and typos in this game. The most predominant one I get is that in exams, if you press an answer as the timer hits 0, the game thinks it should go onto the next question still. So on the final exam, you will get like a 70% but be able to continue on until the end of the questions. This can change your score to a 100%. In these cases I do this exam but then reload at the end and try again. Other bugs have been covered in reviews here, but I don't see them often enough.

Overall, this is a pretty alright learning assistance tool for the language. It does have some flaws that make it not ideal, but they can be overcome with supplementary material. Love Language Japanese is a good starting point for beginners.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980238525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1611375141}
review:
As a learning tool, it's insufficient and buggy. Vocabulary appears in the test segments despite not being mentioned anywhere in the lessons, giving the impression that words were added and removed from the game without any care to maintain consistency. There are also spelling errors. The quizzes are also inadequate. Most practice quizzes are only 5 questions long (you can't make them any longer) and have no safeguards against repeating the same question 3-4 times. It's a crapshoot whether each quiz will be useful, so you just have to spam quizzes over and over again to get any benefit from them. Finally, some of the quiz questions are paired with {B}wrong{/B} answers. So that's fun. Thankfully, that's more the exception than the norm.

As a dating sim, it's formulaic, tedious, and dull. The characters don't even qualify as one dimensional, They're uninteresting, and your interactions with them are (thankfully) short and meaningless. Even the character art is generic and unappealing.

This COULD have been a great concept if the dating sim and lessons were interwoven, but at least as far as I've gotten in the game, this has not yet happened. They're two completely separate elements slapped together. The only thing driving me forward is the lessons, as the sim parts are painful and pointless to sit through.

Therefore, [I]in general[/I] I wouldn't recommend this game. BUT if you just want a study aid / refresher on reading Japanese, I can recommend this IF you just fly through the sim parts. You're not missing anything there. Curb your expectations.

review:
So I'm by no means fluent in Japanese, but I know enough to confidently review this in terms of Japanese content, as well as game content.

If I were to rate this solely on Japanese alone, I'd probably give it a 5 or a 6. There are weekly quizzes which are good, but some of the english translations are wrong (making it impossible for me- someone who actually knows Japanese) to get the right answer, unless I realize they mispelled the word in english. Some content are things people would never say. I did like how they started off with the hiragana and katakana, but it's an ineffective way of learning. People need stories or pneumonics to help them memorize those. 
All this being said, let's go into the game content. The game itself is pretty easy to use, especially when you figure out how to physically call someone. I think the tags are mislabeled though and shouldn't be Japanese content, I think this product is overpriced and you should only consider getting this if you like light novels/ story lines.

review:
Well, in 27.1 hours I have learned the Hiragana, the Katakana, and a few words and sayings in Japanese!!!  I've got my moneys' worth out of this game already.

I really like the idea of using the plot of a gal-ge to drive the player to actually learn a new language.  Having just failed out of the class (for the first time), I can say this...  get a notebook and a pen and be prepared to actually study, like a Japanese student should.  That is what I plan to do, start over with a fresh save and take the language part seriously.

As a tip;  pay attention to and learn all of the vocabulary words well.  If you are not fluent with them later in the game, it will cause you problems later.  You will be reading longer and longer sentences, and translating them against the clock, so you can't look things up very much during the tests.

As a warning;  this game is a bit glitchy, and the English is not so hot....  but the art is, and that might help.  There were times when there were multiple lines of text overwriting each other, but a quick save and reload fixes that.

As a summary;  if you like visual novels and want to learn Japanese in an interesting way, Love Language Japanese is worth the investment in time, money and effort... I think.

I suppose if you don't even know if you're interested, this will give you a taste of Japanese, but nothing beyond that. I know it isn't meant to, so no real disappointment there. 

However, the whole VN and romance part kinda falls flat. You need to play through the game once per waifu and focus all choices on that waifu to see all her events (which is never explained, so your first run through is bound to be a bust). The characters just aren't all that deep or compelling, so it never really felt worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198410080038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 4808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4793, 'last_played': 1570603305}
review:
Hello Everyone, 
This review will be covering developer Papurika Moe’s first published title, “Love Language Japanese”. In this game, players will have the chance to learn the basic aspects of the Hiragana and Katakana writing systems, along with some rudimentary sentence phrases. With that being said, let’s get this review underway. Hope you enjoy
In the words of our best friend Max “Break a Leg”.
Love Language Japanese Is a visual novel style dating simulator that is focused on teaching the player the basic function of the Hiragana and Katakana writing systems. The game does this by enrolling the player into a twelve-week Japanese course where the player will learn the basic Hiragana/Katakana characters and some basic word/phrases in Japanese. During the first three weeks players will learn the 46 Basic Hiragana and Katakana characters; along with their alternate dakuon (20 characters), and handakuon (5 character) forms). To make things simple, you will learn 142 characters by week 3 in the game. From there, the remaining 9 weeks were spent learning numbers, how to tell time, rudimentary sentence congregation, customary pleasantries, how to ask for directions, how to state your likes/dislikes, and how to give a retelling of daily events. The game gives the player several opportunities to practice with the various materials that you learn through out to course of the game, which is always a nice edition to games that focus on teaching the player a new language.
 Before we get any further into this review, I think that it is always important to note that this game is intended to be used as a supplemental resource while you are learning Japanese and not a standalone teaching substitute. With that out of the way, lets continue with the game’s story.  
In this game, the player is entering their first year at Koto Gakuen academy under the misconception of being a third-year Japanese student. This ruse is quickly noticed by the school’s dean and the player is put into a rather precarious situation. The school’s dean decides to not immediately expel you from this prestigious institution, however the player has been played into the school’s first year Japanese learning program and has to past a series of weekly examinations in order to stay at this institution. If the player fails, then they are immediately expelled from the school and is forcefully deported back to their home country. The plot thickens further as this school callously over looked providing their new foreign student housing accommodations at the school. Unbeknownst to the school’s dean, a teacher at the school found this new foreign student housing at her sister’s all girl dormitory. This would not have been an issue if this new student was not a boy. With the game’s stage set the player now has to survive through 12 weeks of gruelling work so your character can continue to live out his dream to live in Japan. 
By the time all of this is covered you should have already made it part way through your first week in the game and thus begins the gameplay. The game operates in day cycles and has around 83 days that the player plays through. These days will start off with the player going through the day’s pre-set morning rituals. Once these are complete the player will continue to the days lesson, which will then be followed by an in-game leisure period. When this passes, the day’s end sequence will occur and once complete the day will end with a new day being on the horizon.
The game’s dating mechanic operates by the player choosing the appropriate text dialog, which will inter progressively fill one of the five dateable girl’s affection gauge. As the player fills this gauge, they will unlock specific dating events that give the player a new Computer Graphic (CG) Art. Each girl has a total of five unlockable CGs (one for each date) which gives the player 25 CGs for dates and around 7 that are unlock as you play through the game. Each day you have an option to choose between, the school, dean’s office, mall, shopping plaza, shrine, restaurant, and garden where you have a chance to running across one of the game’s five dating options during the in-game leisure period. It is also during this time that the dating events will pop by the players in-game phone ringing to signal that on of the girls wants to have a date with you. As you progress through the game, each girl will give you their phone number and this will help you to find their exact location during the game’s leisure period (considering that you only have two chances to choose between the locations be for the end day sequence commences, this is a great way to find out if the girl that you are looking for is available). It is important to not that every girl Is not always available during each leisure session, so it is up to you to adjust your gameplay for the girl that you want to court.   
In the game’s class sections, the player is presented with specific courses of instruction that focus of various aspects of the Japanese writing system. Once a lesson ends, the player can take a five-question quiz to test their retention of the class lesson or continue to the game’s leisure area. During the leisure period, the player could also take the time to receive a practice examination to measure their retention of the course information with a series of ten questions. There is also an option for players to revise their lessons during the game’s end day sequence. Prior to a day’s end, the player has the option to review the lessons that they have taken throughout the course of the game or to take the ten question practice exams. 
The quizzes in the game can have four forms. The first form realizes on questions that require the player to match the appropriate Japanese characters to the appropriate word or phrase. The second realize on the player determining if a specific sentence in English are an equivalent translation for the characters in Japanese. The third quiz realize on questions that require the player to select the appropriate character that completes a specific word or phrase. The forth and final type of quiz realize on questions that require the player to select the appropriate characters that complete a particular sentence. Each quiz in the game has a time limit and minimum score for passing that the player has to be mindful of if they want to progress further into the game. The minimum score for passing is 50% so keep that in mind when you are in the process of completing a particular quiz. 
The game has a decent selection of menu options for the game’s text dialog boxes.  You have the standard load/save buttons as well as a log (which allows you to scroll through previous text dialog that occurred in the game), configurations (which allows you to set the games save options, text dialog boxes, audio, and screen resolution), Title (which allows you to go back to the game’s title screen), Notes (which gives you quick assess to the week’s lessons), and a Girls button (that allows you to see how much you have filled the girl’s affection gauge). There is also an auto button (allows dialog text to automatically progress with out the player’s command) and a skip button (that gives the player the option to skip dialogue they have previously read). The skip function in this game does skip the text dialog but still has the character animations go through their normal movements. This can be irritating when replaying through the game because you don’t have another option to get directly to the character events or the in game quizzes other than this slow skip option. 

The character animation in the game is nicely done and really do help with the story’s overall progression. The character animations are still but this does not detract from the story/imaging because the character images are switched out enough that the emotions/feeling/setting that is being established works with the characters that are in a scene.  

To be continued in comments

review:
It's a great game to learn some basic structure of the Japanese language. I felt as though you might want to play this if you were trying to boost anything you might be missing, if you were studying Japanese in a real class. The test may have annoying and repetitive questions however, and not always are they totally accurate. 
The art style was cool, especially through some of the date sequences; the dating function was pretty straight-forward and basic. And the characters weren't hugely in depth enough to distract you from "School", but it gave enough depth for a bit of emotional attachment. The game is labeled "Nudity", but the most you'll see is bathing suits or some revealing clothing; if it really had any sort of sexual content the people making the game would have labeled it that way. And some choices could use a heads-up so that you can tell whomever you chose to pursue will like or dislike the dialogue, the stats for each woman are basically saying which one YOU like the most. The dialogue is basically the same for every option you choose, and sometimes there are some typos.
I'd like to see perhaps a continuation to the story, or a more refined version of it in the future possibly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991265371', 'num_games_owned': 511, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 965, 'last_played': 1564110578}
review:
What a great concept for a game. I enjoyed revisiting Japanese again for having taken many classes for it. I found it easy and no problem for any of the tests. I have no idea how anyone else would fair against not having taken classes previously but if you're in my position you'll blow through it. That being said if the game wants to teach you Japanese it needs to be more difficult. 

Problems/Suggestions

Every test they give you the same question multiple times.
60 seconds is so short that I'm afraid new learners will struggle. It may increase later but I can imagine some people would struggle
It be cool if there was a writing segment ( trace it with your mouse or maybe if this game was on tablet)
Maybe actual homework where you can make your own sentences 

I noticed some spelling and grammar mistakes here and there. Nothing too often. 

Story is not too bad. It's a typical visual novel with the main character being surrounded by women who find him the most interesting person in the universe. Not a bad thing, it's fun to be around women. All of them written very differently.   
I really have no interest in playing the game again to romance other characters because there's no super fast skip button. Just be sure to pick someone in the beginning and grab every opportunity you can with them. 

There might be a sequel and I'll definitely buy it. 
It would be cool if they had games like this for other languages.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170572873', 'num_games_owned': 445, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1297, 'last_played': 1565977243}
review:
[h1]Что же такое [b]Love Language Japanese?[/b][/h1]

Это классическая визуальная новелла, где в нашем распоряжении имеется пять героинь: Хелен, Сара, Миюки, Профессор Сайто и Дин Ояма. На всё про всё игроку даётся 12 недель, за которые он должен пройти 12 тестов на знание японского и заромансить одну из понравившихся барышень.

Отличительной чертой этой ВН является то, что к игровому процессу добавлена интересная механика обучения основам письменного и разговорного японского. Автоскипом пройти её не получится, ибо придётся потеть над прохождением еженедельного теста на знание пройденного материала. Благо разработчики позаботились о том, чтобы игрок имел возможность в любой момент освежить в памяти любой из пройденных уроков перед началом теста. Сами же тесты построены следующим образом: нужно лишь выбрать правильный ответ из предложенных. При успешном прохождении задания игрок получает возможность продолжить игру. И так до следующего теста. Немного усидчивости, внимательности (или удачи, если вы такой же ленивый как я) и всё получится.

[b][u] ПЛЮСЫ [/u][/b]

[b][i] + Саундтреки[/i][/b]

Приятны слуху и не надоедают. Эта новелла одна из немногих, во время прохождения которых не возникает желания выключить монотонную, быстро успевающую надоесть музыку. Поскольку здесь она таковой не является.

[b][i] + Разнообразие [/i][/b]

[b][i] + История главного героя и диалоги [/i][/b]

Прописаны добротно и интересно. Зачитывался монологами, эмоциональными всплесками, душевными переживаниями и ситуациями из жизни каждой героини. Это, в свою очередь, наделило их своими уникальными чертами личности и неожиданными гранями характера.

[b][u] МИНУСЫ [/u][/b]

Текущий уровень отношений с барышнями можно в любой момент посмотреть, нажав соответствующую кнопку. Это меня немного огорчило, поскольку лично я люблю, когда результат выбора реплики невидим и также невидимо повлияет на дальнейшее прохождение.

Здесь я воздержусь давать какие-либо комментарии т.к. я полный профан в японском. Оставляю систему обучения данной ВН на растерзание игрокам, кто в этом разбирается. Весьма забавная игрушка.

Изучение японского как бы есть (это плюс, наверно), но выучить так вряд ли что-то получится. Разве что азбуки запомнить… но это и без игры делается просто и быстро. Если подобные эксперименты разработчиков вам любопытны, то игру можно брать. Если вы ищите программу для изучения японского, то нет, это не то. Если нужна VN… их много разных, есть из чего выбрать, но и эту попробовать можно.

I was expecting a cliff-notes in the notebook to help refresh my memory of the hiragana I got thrown at me for 30 seconds but the only option is to repeat the lesson entirely, go through the animations and hope you didn't miss anything via misclick. On top of that, the pop quizzes and study sessions are terrible; They are short-burst (5 Problems) that never really randomize and spread over all of the characters you've learned. 

The only good thing I can state about this game for the moment is that it has led me to find online resources in pursuit of a more proper and effective education. This game can be great, it just needs to improve interaction with the player so they can actually memorize the characters they're being taught and offer more resources to help facilitate the learning it boasts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075909503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4144, 'last_played': 1642327759}
review:
Warm Greetings

I have finished the game and would like to offer my first review for a game in steam.

Love Language Japanese is the name and a love of language learning is the game.

The games starts with a scenario that requires regular testing and gives the reasoning behind the requirements to consistently pass the tests,. Along the way the story provide the side incentives of growing the connection with the various love interests and this is a nice break from a purely lesson based approach to learning a language.

The pros
The lessons are broken down to small easy to remember sections of the overall material.
Each lesson has a key point (so its not fully random in the progression of the learning material)
The tests are timed so it forces to think quick enough to make the knowledge second nature.
There are quite a few lessons though the term.
being able to review at the end of each day both with a mock test format and before moving to the next day allows for revision at every step of the way.
The other characters are interesting and though in some ways made cliche by the number of dating sims out there are still worth putting effort into.

The Cons
There could be more types of testing formats to further cement the new material.
The audio is very limited and adding the full list of words in audio would help (this would also help creating an audio only test)
Max is prob the most annoying character in the game.
The naughty side is very mild (this is also a good thing for some) but when providing a reward system giving something a little extra for perfect scores would add a lot of value to the game play.
And lastly the game talks of multiple years of learning Japanese but is only the first year, this makes the games overall material fall short of actually earning the Japanese language. 

In conclusion the game is a great start to learning Japanese and is a fun game to play even if only for the love side of the game, but it could be improved greatly with more language content and even a word database for simply increasing ones ability to comprehend Japanese as a whole. and is worth the money (esp if on sale)

TLDR: its best to buy this game only if your looking for a light way into learning the Japanese language and not as a one stop shop to actually learning the Japanese language as a native speaker (there is still much learning to be done after finishing the game)

review:
Overall I really enjoyed this game but there were a few minor issues I had with it:

1. All of the tests are timed. You only have 60 seconds to answer 10 questions. It's not a big deal at first, but once the questions start becoming more complex and take longer to read, it can feel like you're being rushed. The time limit does eventually increase but not until much later in the game. I strongly recommend you familiarize yourself at least a little bit with hiragana and katakana before playing, since you will be expected to be able to read pretty fast at times and it may be overwhelming for absolute beginners.

2. There are a LOT of typos and grammar mistakes in this game. There weren't any so bad that I couldn't understand what they were trying to say, but there are some lines here and there that you can clearly tell were not written by a native English speaker, and it kinda messes with the flow at times. Nothing too major though.

3. If you're here looking to learn some Kanji, you're gonna be disappointed. There is only one lesson that teaches you any Kanji, and it's not until the very end of the game. It's not really a problem per se, but I think it's something worth mentioning for those interested.



TL;DR this game has its fair share of flaws but it is nonetheless a fun visual novel with interesting characters and you will definitely learn a lot of basic Japanese words and phrases. There are a few ecchi scenes here and there but it's not really that kind of game tbh.

review:
The game is fine, overall, though I'm not exactly sure how well it will teach you any Japanese. The lesson format ends up being too short to really drill anything down, and the tests become more of a speed challenge than anything up until the last 2 or so hours. I already knew a fair bit of Japanese before playing this, though, so I could be wrong.

The biggest problem with the game is the typos. There are only a couple in the first few hours, but the back half is pretty riddled with them, including in some lessons which I'm pretty sure would have been super confusing if I didn't have the little extra Japanese experience I had. The fact that most of the game relies on only hiragana/katakana + romaji is also a huge shame. When sentences become long, it's really hard to parse out what's being said, which is why kanji is a thing.

The girls and story were cute and fine. No real complaints there.

Edit: As a side note, the fact that this is a visual novel that somehow runs poorly drives me nuts. It can't even play the opening theme without stopping and skipping, which is bizarre.

review:
It seems silly. But honestly, this works to teach the very basics of Japanese better than you might expect. It goes slowly and is essentially kindergarten maybe first grade level. But the order it goes in is textbook. 
The quasi-hentai game in between is forgettable. It moves slowly and is box stock male fantasy. 
I'm just surprised that it does a decent job presenting the very basics better than many 'serious' language courses. For example Duolingo assumes you already know quite a bit just to start. This is far more basic and would work well as a primer before starting Duolingo. 
My kid is taking Japanese in college and is impressed with what I have gleaned from this silly title already. 

Strangely enough, this is actually a good investment in learning day one Japanese.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997433571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1553229393}
review:
This is a very chill slice of life game. There's a high emphasis on learning Japanese- katakana, hiragana, and the basics of the language, including sentence structure and commonly used words. Each "day" in the game provides a new lesson and allows the player to choose one person to spend their time with. You can review Japanese lessons at your leisure, and take short pop quizzes to try and memorize the language. It makes for a very nice supplementary way of learning the language without a ton of stress, as long as you accept that you're only learning the basics. The game tests you periodically to make sure you're retaining information.

The plot is very cute and relaxed. The characters all meld well with each other and there's a lot of cute humor linking everyone together. The plot of the game definitely shines thanks to the characters' personalities and interactions.

Thanks to the interesting method of presenting Japanese language education and its relaxed atmosphere, I'd highly recommend Love Language Japanese to anyone with a passing interest in the language. It's a great game to sit back with and just chill for a while.

review:
DO YOU LIKE WAIFUS? DO YOU LIKE JAPANESE? DO YOU NOT MIND SOME OBVIOUS BUT NOT GAME BREAKING ERRORS/ BUGS?

THEN THIS GAME IS FOR YOU! ENJOY THE OVERLY AGRESSIVE TEACHER, TSUNDERE, AND MUCH MORE.

The quizzes are better for review than learning I think. Especially given they have the annoying feature of giving you the same question a couple times in a row sometimes. 

It covers the material you'd need, but again you'd have to watch the lessons a few times and if your goal is to learn Japanese there's YouTube videos that do it a bit better. But again, it's a good, if basic, review tool.

There's a few other visual bugs I've run into, but mostly nothing major. Some typos as well, although I haven't noticed any in the tests, just in normal dialouge. There was one lesson where the text wouldn't load and I was stuck, but good old "reload and spam spacebar" worked fine. At least the autosave worked well :p

But really I enjoy this game. I'm not quite finished, but the characters are cute, the story decent, the japanese language review solid. The bugs are annoying but they're actively patching them. It has no voice acting so if you hate that I guess don't buy it. Solid 8/10.

review:
It may seem like there are more cons than pros, but this is a great game if you intend on actually learning the building blocks of Japanese (but lack the motivation to read a textbook). Unlike its rivals, the pacing is quite fast, which is refreshingly challenging. You learn about 15 characters + 12 words every week. If you're a beginner, this is not a game that you could keep playing without making some actual notes irl. Don't expect to rush through the game just to date the girls - you likely won't remember everything they've taught you (which gives you a game over). Of course, you could always savescum, but then what's the point? Just buy a regular dating sim/vn that focuses more on story and character development.

I do have a few complaints though: 
1. Protagonist does not have a name. This makes it difficult to tell apart his speech, his thoughts, and general narration.

2. Certain words in quizzes have not been learned in previous lessons. E.g. In the pop quiz after lesson 4, word "Wings" appeared but was not covered.

3. Interaction is a bit fragmented. For example,[spoiler]before you pass the first Saturday test, there's some dialogue with Sarah, where she's worried about you failing and tells you that she'll wait for you at the house. However, after you pass, she's not there anymore. I called her and went to her location (I think at the park?), and she seems to be have completely forgotten about our conversation earlier.[/spoiler]

4. Continuing from #3, speaking of[spoiler]Sarah, she tells you quite a bit of personal detail during your first time alone with her. Maybe it's intended and she's just an open book, but it felt a bit awkward and out of place.[/spoiler]

5. Lastly, the MC's personality is a bit inconsistent. He's usually shy and awkward when [spoiler]Helen and Ms.Saito tease him, but is somehow able to lecture/scold Helen when she accidentally made Sarah feel bad.[/spoiler] It just felt out of place.

tldr: This is a game that teaches the basics of Japanese with dating elements tacked on, not the other way around. Not recommended for those only interested in the girls.

It would be nice to just be able to something instead of doing nothing on that day. I don't know if it's just my game, but I think there may be a bug with the dates and CG pictures. review:
I've only been playing this game around 2 hours and I was surprisingly impressed at what it offers. The storyline and relationship progression feels like an early 2000's eroge game with quite a bit of steroetypical characters, but it's pop quizes and lessons are actually quite informative.

I've gotten as far as lesson 5 and I was surprised that certain sentences no longer contain romanji (which I've never been mucha fan of).  This makes the level of progression quite intuitive. That being said, I'm not sure how effective the lessons are considering I already know hiragana and katakana and some of the explanations seem to be pulled off some of the more popular language textbooks minus the in-depth explanations. So for absolute begginers at Japanese, it might not be a good starting game. There's also the fact that there's no voice acting, which may affect how non-speakers read the text in their heads. 

Overall, if this is your sole source of studying Japanese, it needa more work. But as a supplement to other more traditional methods, it's a fun way to test yourself and level up your skills.

review:
Okay, right now I am going to give this game a recommendation in hopes that it will do better as I understand both budget constraints as well as the work put into the game is definitely worth experiencing. Also I am factoring in the fact I have only played up to week 2. However, I do wish there was more engaging dialogue within the game's first few weeks. I understand the the first few weeks are supposed to build the foundations for Japanese, however I do believe that engagement is an extremely important aspect in order to both enhance the experience, and keeping the player engaged and immersed within the game. So far, while I agree with the responses that the protagonist is making, and do enjoy his humane and fleshed nature which is a nice contrast to traditional visual novel protagonists, I don't quite get the same feeling from the girls in the game. The dialogue of the girls is quite static with barely one line of response so far to choices. I would like the game to do more than just express one line, especially in these first few weeks where it is important to keep up motivation for newer players of the game. But also I would like to see some time management done in the game. The days feel so short and I find it a little disturbing that I can somehow study forever into the night XD. All jokes aside, I do think that the first couple of weeks in terms of story feel a bit rushed which does ruin the pacing of the narrative. I hope that this game does improve as I keep playing.

Kind Regards,

review:
O gráfico do jogo é realmente maravilhoso, apesar de não existir dublagem nas falas existe uma narração da pronúncia das palavras durante as aulas. 

Além do básico que todo jogo e curso grátis ensina, sobre os caracteres e algumas palavras, o jogo aborda a questão gramatical, explicando sobre particulas, pronomes, etc.

Sobre o relacionamento dos personagens eu não sei até que ponto vai, como tem a tag de conteúdo sexual, estou 1000% motivado, seria uma excelência um jogo que se dispõe a ir tão longe dentro da sua temática, visual novel com o "plus" de aprendizado. Mas devo ressaltar que as interelções entre os personagens são curtas e vão direto ao ponto, acho que ficou ideal, sem perder tempo com assuntos desnecessários que você logo perderá o interesse em ficar lendo.

-EDIT
Apesar das tags o jogo não tem nudez nem conteúdo sexual, o mais perto são os os frames de beijo (sim, é um CG estático com as falas) e as famosas cenas no banheiro onde a mulher ensaboada lava as costas do personagem, mas o protagonista está com uma toalha e a parceira ou de biquine ou com uma roupa de banho escrota.

Se quiser tirar máximo proveito do jogo reocomendo que baixe os app para smartphone (2 hour hiragana e 2 hour katakana), tira 1 ou 2 semanas para aprender todos esses kanas e depois estuda a parte gramatical no jogo. 

Estou decepcionado pela falta de putaria, levarei isso em conta caso a empresa lance outros jogos. A historia não é ruim apesar de tudo, só comprei pelas portarias e não recebi isso. Nem nudez, nem peitcholas. O que eu estou fazendo da minha vida?


Nota: 10/10

O que pode melhorar?
- A voz gravada na pronúncia das palavras é MUITO baixa se comparada com os outros soms dentro do jogo
- As vezes quando você pega um teste na parte da tarde aparecem algumas palavras que são da lição do outro dia. Encaro isso como um desafio, mas acho que é um bug.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099423285', 'num_games_owned': 806, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 975, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 761, 'last_played': 1706394072}
review:
Estoy estudiando japonés en la universidad y estuve esperando este juego para ver si aparte de un buen rato, reforzaba mis conocimientos del idioma. La verdad está muy bien, igual que en una escuela, y como debería ser. Te enseñan primero Hiragana y vocabulario, luego Katakana y más vocabulario, sigues por frases simples como decir: "Gracias" o "Esto es una computadora" y me supongo que luego seguirán los kanjis. Eso si, el juego está en inglés así que tu experiencia con el juego será inglés-japonés. 

Cada día tienes interacciones con las chicas por las mañanas, luego vas a una clase de japonés y puedes salir por la tarde a platicar con la chica de tu elección, por las noches se te da la opción de repasar todo lo aprendido ese día y anteriores, y la verdad si ayuda mucho, más que nada por el vocabulario, y porque pasar los miniexamenes diarios/semanales son necesarios para progresar en la historia. 

La música es tranquila, da una buena ambientación y las chicas tienen una personalidad bonita, típico de este tipo de juegos, claro está, pero ayuda mucho al ambiente de aprendizaje.

Si no sabes nada de japonés mas que lo que has visto en anime o así, te recomendaría que te tomes con calma este juego, tómate el tiempo con cada día que pasa, repasa los carácteres que ves cada día, pues para las 3 semanas in-game, ya debiste aprender todo la escritura hiragana y katakana. 

Espero te guste este juego.

A great game, but here's some bugs.

Some known bugs/problems I've came across so far:

7. The volume configuration (not sure if its the same with other settings) resets after the game is closed

9. Some CGs in the galleryare unlocked before you even get that CG in the playthrough, for me, all sarah and helen dates were unlocked before I even got to date 3

None of these are game breaking bugs by any means but it would be nice to see it get fixed
